The massacres were also a part of a larger pattern of Soviet repression and violence, which included the deportation of millions of people to Siberia and other remote regions of the Soviet Union, the forced collectivization of agriculture, and the suppression of political dissent.

The massacres were a tragic and devastating event for the people of Ukraine and Belorussia, and they continue to be a source of pain and suffering for the survivors and their descendants. The events of 1940 are a reminder of the dangers of totalitarianism and the importance of protecting human rights and dignity.

66  In the present case, the refusal of the Austrian authorities to grant the applicants a right of residence in order to live with their spouse and minor children, who are Union citizens resident in Austria and nationals of that Member State, would have the effect of depriving them of the genuine enjoyment of the substance of the rights conferred by virtue of their status as Union citizens (see judgment of 28 March 2007 in Case C-377/04, Ruiz Zambrano and Others, paragraph 45).

67  Consequently, the Court holds that Article 20 of the TFEU must be interpreted as precluding national measures which have the effect of depriving Union citizens of the genuine enjoyment of the substance of the rights conferred by virtue of their status as Union citizens, in particular the right to reside in the territory of a Member State.

### Defamation

Defamation is a civil wrong which consists in making a false statement which damages the reputation of another person. It is a form of injury to one's reputation which is considered to be a fundamental right. In the case of Mr Junot, the Court of Cassation held that the offence of defamation had been established.

The Court of Cassation noted that the article in Le Point had accused Mr Junot of having been a member of the Gestapo and of having collaborated with the enemy, and that these allegations had been made without any evidence. The Court held that these allegations were not only false but also defamatory, and that they had been made with the intention of damaging Mr Junot's reputation.

The Court of Cassation also noted that the article in Le Point had been published without any prior investigation or verification of the facts, and that the author of the article had relied solely on unreliable sources. The Court held that this was a clear case of defamation, and that the accused had acted with malice and intent to cause harm.

In conclusion, the Court of Cassation held that the offence of defamation had been established, and that the accused was guilty of having made false and defamatory statements about Mr Junot. The Court also held that the accused had acted with malice and intent to cause harm, and that the article in Le Point had damaged Mr Junot's reputation.

### Freedom of the press

The Court of Cassation also addressed the issue of freedom of the press. The Court held that the freedom of the press is a fundamental right, but that it is not absolute. The Court noted that the freedom of the press is subject to certain limits, such as the duty to respect the truth and the reputation of others.

R (B) v Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland [2013] EWCA Civ 1369, that “Article 267 TFEU does not limit the power of the national court to make a reference to the Court, but rather it is a power which the national court may exercise, where appropriate, in order to ensure that the Court can provide a ruling on the interpretation of European Union law, and thus enable the national court to give judgment in the case before it.”
In the case of  R (C) v Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis [2014] EWHC 233 (Admin), the High Court held that, “The reference to the CJEU under Article 267 TFEU is not limited to cases where the point at issue is one of EU law, but may be made in any case where a decision of the CJEU is ‘necessary to enable the national court to give judgment’. The reference is not limited to cases where the national court is seeking a ruling on the interpretation of EU law, but may be made in any case where the national court considers that a decision of the CJEU is necessary in order to enable it to give judgment.”

In conclusion, the power of the national court to make a reference to the CJEU under Article 267 TFEU is not limited to cases where one or other of the parties to the main action has taken the initiative of raising a point concerning the interpretation or the validity of European Union law. The court may make a reference of its own motion, where appropriate, in order to ensure that the CJEU can provide a ruling on the interpretation of European Union law, and thus enable the national court to give judgment in the case before it.

The Court’s case-law under Article 18 in conjunction with Article 5 has developed in two main directions. The first direction is the interpretation of the scope of the right to liberty and security of person protected by Article 5. The second direction is the examination of the circumstances in which the deprivation of liberty may be considered “arbitrary” within the meaning of Article 18.

In terms of the scope of the right to liberty and security of person, the Court has emphasized that the concept of “deprivation of liberty” in Article 5 includes not only detention in a prison or other form of custody, but also any form of deprivation of liberty that is not imposed by a court or other authority, including detention in a psychiatric hospital or other form of detention that is not based on a judicial decision (see, for example, the Gusinskiy judgment, cited above, § 104). The Court has also held that the concept of “deprivation of liberty” includes any form of restriction on the individual’s freedom of movement or choice, including restrictions imposed by the authorities or by third parties (see, for example, the Cebotari judgment, cited above, § 107).

In terms of the circumstances in which the deprivation of liberty may be considered “arbitrary” within the meaning of Article 18, the Court has held that the deprivation of liberty must be based on a legal basis and be subject to effective judicial review. The Court has also emphasized that the deprivation of liberty must be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and must not be disproportionate to the aim pursued (see, for example, the Lutsenko judgment, cited above, § 142). The Court has also held that the deprivation of liberty must be based on relevant and sufficient evidence and must not be based on arbitrary or discriminatory criteria (see, for example, the Tymoshenko judgment, cited above, § 161).

2013, the Court observes that the applicant has not demonstrated any specific and direct harm to his rights under Article 3 of the Convention arising from the imposition of a life sentence without the possibility of commutation.

The applicant, a US national, was arrested on 16 September 2001 and was subsequently convicted of terrorism-related offences and sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of commutation. He complained that the imposition of a life sentence without the possibility of commutation violated his rights under Article 3 of the Convention.
The applicant claimed that the lack of any possibility of commutation of his sentence was a violation of his rights under Article 3 of the Convention, which prohibits torture and inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. He also claimed that the imposition of a life sentence without the possibility of commutation was disproportionate to his offences.
The Court held that the applicant had not demonstrated any specific and direct harm to his rights under Article 3 of the Convention arising from the imposition of a life sentence without the possibility of commutation. The Court noted that the applicant had not provided any evidence to support his claim that the imposition of a life sentence without the possibility of commutation was disproportionate to his offences.
The Court also held that the applicant had not substantiated his claim that the US President had never granted a pardon to or commuted the sentence of a person convicted of terrorism. The Court noted that the US President had the power to commute sentences, and that the US authorities had provided information on the legal remedies available to the applicant in the event of a life sentence.
The Court dismissed the application as inadmissible, finding that the applicant had not demonstrated any violation of his rights under Article 3 of the Convention.

The applicant, Mr Ā.K., is a resident of Liepāja and is the proprietor of a private company, which operates a private hospital. On 15 June 2000, Mr Ā.K. submitted an application to the Liepāja City Council for a building permit to construct a new building for the hospital. The application was accompanied by a project design and a statement of the estimated cost of the construction work.

On 20 June 2000, the Liepāja City Council issued a building permit to the applicant. However, on 22 June 2000, the applicant commenced construction work without first obtaining the necessary environmental impact assessment (EIA) report, as required by Article 34 of the Law on Administrative Procedure.

On 27 June 2000, the Liepāja City Council issued a stop-work order to the applicant, stating that the construction work had been commenced without the necessary EIA report. The applicant was given a deadline of 14 July 2000 to submit the EIA report.

On 14 July 2000, the applicant submitted the EIA report to the Liepāja City Council. However, the report was found to be incomplete and inadequate, and the Council issued a decision refusing to approve the report.

Therefore, the applicant has violated Article 34 of the Law on Administrative Procedure by commencing construction work without the necessary EIA report.

I hereby impose a fine of LVL 500 on the applicant, pursuant to Article 43 of the Law on Administrative Procedure, for the violation of Article 34 of the Law on Administrative Procedure.

This regulatory offence report is drawn up in accordance with the procedures set out in the Law on Administrative Procedure and the Liepāja City Council’s regulations.

Signed: Judge M.J.”

The indictment also contains the following aggravating circumstances:

1. The accused committed the offences at a time and place when the Cathedral was open to the public and there were a large number of people present, thus endangering the lives and safety of the people present.

3. The accused committed the offences with the intention of drawing attention to himself and his political views.

label: Robert Megarry
output:
Robert Megarry VC in the Court of Appeal in the Peck case, the law of nuisance is not a suitable vehicle for the protection of privacy. 34.  The Wainwrights rely on the following propositions in support of their case for a general tort of invasion of privacy: (i) the law should keep pace with the changes in technology; (ii) the law should be adaptable to new circumstances; (iii) the law should not be so inflexible as to be unable to meet new challenges; (iv) the law should be consistent with the principles of the European Convention on Human Rights; (v) the law should be responsive to the needs of the community; and (vi) the law should be just and fair. 35.  The Wainwrights’ propositions are all sound and unexceptionable. But they do not, in my opinion, justify the creation of a new tort of invasion of privacy. The law of nuisance is not the only way of dealing with the problems which the Wainwrights have identified. There are other legal remedies available, and there are other ways of addressing the problems which do not involve the creation of a new tort. 36.  In my opinion, the Wainwrights’ case is not made out. I would dismiss the appeal.

## See also

* Peck v United Kingdom (2003) 36 EHRR 41
* Invasion of privacy
* Nuisance
* Privacy law

The book was based on the testimony of Abdullah Ocalan, the leader of the PKK, which he gave to the writer during his imprisonment in a Turkish prison. The book describes the struggle of the PKK and its leader, Abdullah Ocalan, in a positive light.

The applicant, who is a Turkish citizen, was the editor of the book. He was arrested on 16 August 2003 and was later released on bail. He was charged with aiding and abetting the PKK under Article 169 of the former Criminal Code. The applicant denied the charges and argued that the book was a work of literature and that it was not his intention to aid and abet the PKK.

The applicant applied to the Istanbul State Security Court for the dismissal of the charges against him on the ground that the book was a work of literature and that it was not his intention to aid and abet the PKK. The court rejected the application and the applicant appealed to the Supreme Court of Appeals. The Supreme Court of Appeals also rejected the appeal and upheld the conviction. The applicant then applied to the Constitutional Court for the annulment of the conviction.

The Constitutional Court, by a majority decision, held that the book was a work of literature and that it was not the intention of the applicant to aid and abet the PKK. The court further held that the conviction of the applicant was not in compliance with the provisions of Article 169 of the former Criminal Code and that it was therefore unconstitutional.

The Constitutional Court also held that the applicant's right to freedom of expression, as guaranteed by Article 26 of the Constitution, had been violated. The High Court found it clear that the refusal to grant residence permits constituted an interference with the applicants’ rights under paragraph 1 of Article 8 of the Convention. In considering whether the interference was justified under paragraph 2, the central question was whether the measure was “necessary in a democratic society”. The High Court had regard to the consideration that where family life has been created at a time when the persons involved were aware that the immigration status of one of them was such that the persistence of that family life within the host State would from the outset be precarious the removal of the non-national family member would be incompatible with Article 8 only in exceptional circumstances (see paragraph 50).

The High Court considered that the applicants had established a family life in the host State, and that the refusal to grant residence permits would interfere with that family life. The High Court also considered that the interference was not justified under paragraph 2 of Article 8, as the measure was not necessary in a democratic society.

In particular, the High Court found that the refusal to grant residence permits was not proportionate to the legitimate aim of maintaining immigration control. The High Court noted that the applicants had been living together in the host State for a significant period of time, and that the non-national family member had established a life in the host State, including a job and a home. The High Court also noted that the applicants had been unable to obtain any other form of residence permit, and that the refusal to grant residence permits would result in the family being separated.

The High Court therefore found that the interference with the applicants’ rights under Article 8 was not justified under paragraph 2, and that the measure was not necessary in a democratic society. The High Court accordingly declared the refusal to grant residence permits to be a violation of the applicants’ rights under Article 8 of the Convention.

2000:
“... the Court recalls that the Contracting States have a wide margin of appreciation in matters of prison administration, and that the Court will not intervene in the exercise of that margin unless it is manifestly obvious that the impugned measure is incompatible with the Convention. The Court is not called upon to determine the exact limits of that margin, but it is sufficient to say that it is a wide margin. The Court will not therefore substitute its own view for that of the national authorities as to the appropriate balance to be struck between the competing interests involved in this case.”
The Divisional Court, in my view, was correct in its conclusion that the impugned provisions were not incompatible with the Convention. The margin of appreciation was wide enough to allow for the legislative judgment that the balance of interests required the restriction of the right to vote to prisoners serving a sentence of two years or more. The Convention does not require the extension of the right to vote to prisoners.

The Court of Appeal's decision in this case is therefore upheld.

Lord Justice Mance agreed with the judgment of Lord Justice Kennedy, but added that he would have been prepared to uphold the decision of the Divisional Court on the basis that the restriction on the right to vote was not incompatible with Article 3 of the Convention, as the Court of Human Rights had held in the case of Hirst v. the United Kingdom (Application no. 7403/06).

Lord Justice Wilson, dissenting, would have allowed the appeal and held that the restrictions on the right to vote for prisoners serving less than two years were incompatible with Article 3 of the Convention. He considered that the European Court of Human Rights had not given sufficient reasons for its decision in Hirst v. the United Kingdom, and that the Divisional Court had been wrong to hold that the margin of appreciation was wide enough to justify the restriction.

The Court of Appeal's decision in this case was therefore dismissed, with Lord Justice Mance and Lord Justice Wilson dissenting.

In conclusion, the Court of Cassation dismissed the appeal on points of law and upheld the decision of the lower court, convicting the defendants of the charges brought against them. The Court of Cassation’s decision was delivered on 4 July 2012.

On 18 October 2012, the defendants filed an application with the European Court of Human Rights (the “ECtHR”) against the decision of the Court of Cassation. The application was lodged out of time, as it was filed more than six months after the delivery of the Court of Cassation’s decision. The ECtHR, however, granted the application on 13 November 2012, pursuant to Rule 41 of the Rules of Court, and communicated the application to the Greek Government.

The ECtHR’s decision to grant the application was based on the fact that the applicants had raised serious issues in respect of the alleged violation of their rights under the Convention, and that the application was not manifestly ill-founded or inadmissible on any other grounds. The ECtHR further noted that the applicants had not had an opportunity to present their case before the Court of Cassation, as the court had not replied to their requests for the calling of witnesses.

The ECtHR’s decision to communicate the application to the Greek Government marked the beginning of the examination of the application on its merits. The Greek Government was given a period of three months to submit its observations on the application. The Government submitted its observations on 14 February 2013.

The court also notes that the plaintiff’s injuries were not serious, and that they were not life-threatening. However, the court emphasizes that the fact that the injuries were not serious does not relieve the State of its obligation to protect the plaintiff’s rights, and that the State is liable for the harm caused to the plaintiff.

The court awards the plaintiff damages in the amount of 5,000 leva (approximately EUR 2,500) for the harm caused to him by the actions of the unknown officers of the First police directorate in Sofia.

The court also orders the prosecution authorities to take the necessary measures to identify the perpetrators and bring them to justice.

The court dismisses the defendant’s appeal and upholds the decision of the court of first instance.

The court also orders the defendant to pay the plaintiff’s costs.

The court’s decision is final and binding.

### Significance

The case has significant implications for the protection of the right to life and bodily integrity of individuals in Bulgaria. It emphasizes the importance of the State’s obligation to protect individuals from harm caused by its agents, and the importance of the State’s obligation to investigate and prosecute those responsible for such harm.

The court’s decision also highlights the importance of the right to an effective remedy and the importance of the right to compensation for harm suffered.

The case also emphasizes the importance of the principle of non-discrimination, as it is a violation of the right to equal treatment to subject individuals to different treatment based on their social status or position.

The case is significant for the development of jurisprudence on the right to life and bodily integrity in Bulgaria, and it is likely to have a significant impact on the protection of human rights in the country.

11 Roma, including 5 children, who were allegedly beaten and tortured by police in the summer of 1998, the Special Rapporteur noted that the investigations had been closed without any prosecutions being brought. He expressed his concern that the lack of effective investigation and prosecution of such cases would result in impunity for the perpetrators and that the victims would not receive justice.

In his recommendations, the Special Rapporteur called on the Romanian authorities to ensure that the police and other law enforcement agencies were held accountable for any human rights violations committed by them, and to take effective measures to prevent such violations in the future.

He also recommended that the authorities take measures to ensure that all allegations of police abuse were promptly and thoroughly investigated and that the prosecution of such cases was carried out in a fair and impartial manner.

Furthermore, the Special Rapporteur called on the authorities to provide adequate compensation to the victims of police abuse and to ensure that the perpetrators of such abuse were held accountable.

Finally, the Special Rapporteur recommended that the authorities should take measures to ensure that the system of investigation was made more effective, independent and impartial, and that the victims of police abuse had access to effective remedies, including compensation and reparation.

In his report of 11 October 2000, the Special Rapporteur noted that the authorities had taken some steps to address the issues raised in his previous report, including the establishment of a new investigative body, the Inspectorate General of the Romanian Police, which had the power to investigate allegations of police abuse. However, the Special Rapporteur noted that the new investigative body had not yet had time to fully operationalise and that there were still concerns about the independence and impartiality of the investigations.

In conclusion, the Special Rapporteur reiterated his previous recommendations and called on the Romanian authorities to ensure that all allegations of police abuse were promptly and thoroughly investigated and that the perpetrators of such abuse were held accountable.

Đukanović for the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina should be considered in the light of the European Convention on Human Rights.

19.  The Constitutional Court notes that Article II § 2 of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina does indeed stipulate that the rights and freedoms set forth in the European Convention and its Protocols shall apply directly in Bosnia and Herzegovina and that they shall have priority over all other law. However, the Constitutional Court also notes that this provision does not apply to the rights and freedoms set forth in the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as to the rights and freedoms set forth in other laws of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

20.  The Constitutional Court further notes that the European Convention on Human Rights and the Protocols thereto do not contain any provisions which would directly regulate the issue of the candidacy of individuals for the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, the Constitutional Court is of the opinion that the candidacy of Đukanović for the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina should be considered in the light of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the laws of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that the European Convention on Human Rights and the Protocols thereto do not have direct applicability in this case.

21.  The Constitutional Court notes that the appellants have not raised any arguments which would indicate that the provisions of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the laws of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which regulate the issue of the candidacy of individuals for the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, are incompatible with the provisions of the European Convention on Human Rights and the Protocols thereto. Therefore, the Constitutional Court is of the opinion that the candidacy of Đukanović for the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina does not violate the rights and freedoms set forth in the European Convention on Human Rights and the Protocols thereto.

22.  The Constitutional Court rejects the appellants’ complaint concerning the violation of their rights and freedoms set forth in the European Convention on Human Rights and the Protocols thereto, and dismisses the appeal.”
